summary: This is an FBI interview transcript (302 form) of a former Deutsche Bank relationship coordinator who worked on the Jeffrey Epstein account under private banker Paul Morris. The interviewee describes the bank's due diligence process, her compilation of a research memo on Epstein's criminal background, the high-risk designation of the accounts, and her interactions with Epstein's associates regarding wire transfers and compliance alerts.

connections.description: Paul Morris was the private banker at Deutsche Bank who brought Jeffrey Epstein on as a client. Epstein was his only client during the witness's time on the team.
Paul Morris reported to Chip Packard, who held a senior role at the private bank.
Richard Kahn was Jeffrey Epstein's accountant, responsible for sending wire requests and handling financial matters.
Darren Indyke was a power of attorney for Jeffrey Epstein, authorized to act on his behalf.
The witness worked as a relationship coordinator under private banker Paul Morris, assisting with due diligence, KYC, and wire processing for his client, Jeffrey Epstein.
Leon Black was a potential client Paul Morris sought an introduction to, possibly through the Epstein connection. The witness researched opening an account for Black.

events.title: Witness begins working with Paul Morris
events.description: The witness started working under private banker Paul Morris at Deutsche Bank, initially helping with other clients before focusing on the Jeffrey Epstein account.

events.title: Witness leaves Paul Morris's team
events.description: The witness requested to leave Paul Morris's team due to a poor working relationship and discomfort working with his only client, Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI Webex Interview
events.description: The FBI conducted a Webex interview with a former Deutsche Bank relationship coordinator regarding the bank's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein account.

locations: 345 Park Avenue (Deutsche Bank office location mentioned)
Epstein's various homes (referenced in context of accounts used for upkeep and wages)
keyFacts: A Deutsche Bank employee compiled a detailed open-source research memo on Jeffrey Epstein's criminal convictions for sex offenses, which was presented to senior bank officials Chip Packard and Patrick Harris.
The bank decided to open accounts for Epstein under company names he owned, not in his personal name, to mitigate reputational risk, despite him being the beneficial owner.
The Epstein accounts were designated as 'high-risk,' requiring more stringent KYC procedures, annual reviews, and additional approvals for transactions.
The witness felt pressure to process wire transfers and clear compliance alerts quickly for the Epstein team, though she states there was no pressure to violate procedures.
Wire transfers to various women and entities were noted, and while the witness had suspicions they might be related to past misconduct, she believed more senior officials were reviewing them.
